rule: Like in many languages, the verb ‚sein‘ looks very different when conjugated. Learn the conjugation!
The most important German small talk question literally translates to ‚How is it going with you?‘
There are two different verbs in German for ‘to live’ and ‘to live somewhere’

example: Er hat einen Bruder und eine Schwester.
Ich studiere an der Universität in Leipzig.
rule: Beware of this false friend: ‚studieren‘ in German is only used for studying at a ‚Universität‘ or ‚Fachhochschule‘, not general studying i.e. in a German class.

example: Ich spreche Englisch, Türkisch und ein bisschen Deutsch.
rule: When conjugating this verb, note that the vocal changes from ‚e‘ to ‚i‘ in 2. and 3. person singular.
Just like in English, you can use ‚verdienen‘ when talking about money, but also respect etc.

example: Hast du dein Buch schon eingepackt?
rule: ‚packen‘ and ‚einpacken‘ are not the same like in English. ‚einpacken‘ means that you put an object, like a book, into another, like a bag – or wrapping paper!

example: Erzähl mal! Was hast du heute gelernt?

rule: The verb ‚passieren‘ in ist most common use (to happen) can only be combined with ‚inactive‘ subjects like ‚es‘, ‚das‘, ‚sowas‘, never ‚active subjects‘ like ‚ich‘, ‚er‘ etc.

example: Wir haben noch keine Information gekriegt.
